PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
1.  A  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  for  $700,000  in  grant  funds  is 
included in the 2012-2014 COBP for India. Based on the due diligence requirements, this PPTA 
is being requested for $350,000. 
 
A.  Justification 
2.  PPTA is required to carry out proper due diligence on technical, economic, financial, 
social and environmental aspects of the Program as well as the tranche 1 sub-projects. The 
PPTA will assess the requirements for capacity development in Maha Genco to implement PPP 
projects. Needs assessment will be conducted for overall capacity building of Maha Genco and 
Maha Transco, and assistance in preparing necessary framework documents for the MFF.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
3.  The outputs of this PPTA are a fully prepared MFF and Tranche 1 loan. This includes 
completed  social  and  environmental  analysis  and  documentation,  technical,  economic  and 
financial due diligence, and a capacity development and implementation support component.

D.  Consulting Services 
6.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended). A total of 7 positions and 16 person-months of consulting 
services are required. Individual consultants will be engaged for 4 positions for 9 person-
months,  namely,  the  Solar  Power  Generation  Technology  Specialist,  the  Sector  Policy 
Specialist  and  the  Social  and  Environmental  Safeguards  Specialists,  as  their  services  are 
required to commence at the earliest. The remaining 3 positions for 7 person-months would be 
recruited through a firm by obtaining a biodata technical proposal, following the quality- and 
cost-based selection method with 80% weight for quality and 20% weight for price. To expedite 
project processing, advanced contracting procedures will be adopted, so that the consultants 
can be on board soon after the TA is effective. Work to be performed by the consultants 
includes (i) technical assessment of the proposed solar power generation and transmission 
program; (ii) capacity assessment of the EAs, and suggested remedial action plan to build EA 
capacity to minimize procurement, financial management and governance risks; (iii) preparation 
of bid documents and a procurement plan for tranche 1; (iv) preparation of  social safeguards 
framework documents, and social safeguards due diligence for tranche 1; (v) preparation of 
environmental safeguards framework document and environmental safeguards due diligence for 
tranche 1; (vi) economic and financial due diligence for the tranche 1; and (vii) assessing the 
readiness of Maha Genco to adopt the PPP modality for developing solar power generation

7.  The outline terms of references for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paras. 8 to 15. 
  
8.  Solar Power Generation Technology Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The 
consultant should possess a university bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering, and 5 years 
experience  in  working  in  solar  power  generation  projects,  and  knowledge  of  ADB  loan 
processing modalities. The consultant should review the solar park DPRs for technical viability, 
and prepare full technical descriptions, bid documents and procurement plans for the tranche 1 
loan  subprojects.  The  consultant  would  review  the  project  planning,  procurement  and 
implementation  capabilities  of  both  EAs,  and  include  recommendations  for  capacity 
development during the duration of the MFF. 
  
9.  Transmission and System Operations Specialist (international, 2 person-months). 
The consultant should have a university bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering or system 
operations, and 5 years experience in establishing and/or planning for development of grid 
operations  centers,  including  the  integration  of  renewable  energy  generation  from  diverse 
sources. The consultant would assist the Maha Transco to develop the recommendations for 
the  Renewable  Energy  Control  Center,  including  a  road-map  for  phased  implementation, 
technical descriptions, bid documents and procurement plan.  He/She would organize a study 
visit to facilitate the study of renewable energy control technology. 
 
10.  Sector Policy Specialist (national, 2 person-months). The consultant should have a 
university bachelor’s degree in engineering, economics, management accounting or business 
administration, and 10 years experience in the energy sector. He/She would develop a roadmap 
and the strategic context for the MFF investment program, including a policy matrix, a list of key 
issues  and  constraints,  and  undertakings.  He/She  should  provide  an  assessment  of  the 
prevailing national and state policies relating to renewable energy on such issues as availability 
and trend of feed-in-tariff, tax exemptions, the renewable energy investment in Maharashtra and 
its performance over the last several years, a credit quality analysis of the offtakers, and 
differences between India and other countries. 
  
11.  Economics  and  Financial  Specialist  (national,  4  person-months).  The  consultant 
should have a university bachelor’s degree in engineering, economics, management accounting 
or business administration, and 10 years experience in analyzing energy sector projects. The 
consultant will conduct the financial assessments for the tranche 1 subprojects in accordance

20  Appendix  5   
with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). The consultant will convert 
the financial costs and prices into economic prices, and carry out an economic analysis of the 
tranche 1 subprojects following ADB’s Guidelines on Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
12.  Social Development Specialist (international, 3 person-months). The consultant should 
have a university bachelor’s degree in sociology, anthropology or social sciences, and 15 years 
overall  experience.  The  consultant  will  review  the  legal  policies  on  land  acquisition  and 
involuntary resettlement to verify adequacy and consistency with ADB's SPS, and recommend 
measures  to  bridge  any  gap.  The  consultant  will  prepare  a  Resettlement  Framework  and 
Indigenous  People’s  Development  Framework  (if  required),  a  Resettlement  Plan  and  a 
Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy for tranche 1 subprojects. The consultant will 
engage in a consultative process with affected groups, and collect socioeconomic data in the 
relevant adjacent communities, and identify potential gender, social, employment generation, 
and health impact issues. 
 
13.  Environmental Safeguards Specialist (international 2 person-months). The consultant 
should have at least a university bachelor’s degree in environmental sciences, and an overall 
experience of about 15 years including about 10 years in the energy sector. The consultant will 
prepare an Environmental Assessment and Review Framework for the proposed Program in 
accordance  with  ADB's  SPS  and  prepare  Environmental  Impact  Assessment  or  Initial 
Environmental Examination reports for the tranche 1 investments.  
 
14.  PPP  Specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  The  consultant  should  have  a 
bachelor’s degree in business administration, finance, management accountancy or economics, 
and  10  years  experience  in  structuring  capital  investment  projects  with  PPP  elements, 
preferably in the energy sector. The consultant will assess the legal, institutional and regulatory 
environment in Maharashtra and Maha Genco to facilitate PPP investments in solar power 
generation. The consultant would (i) organize two workshops to promote solar park investments 
in Maharashtra and assess investor expectations; (ii) develop an institutional mechanism for 
interaction  between  the  investors,  the  government  and  Maha  Genco;  and  (iii)  provide 
recommendations for capacity development of Maha Genco to form and nurture PPP joint 
ventures. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The executing agencies (EA) for the TA will be the Maha Genco and Maha Transco. The 
EAs will provide in-kind contributions by providing office accommodation, support facilities, 
counterpart staff, maps, reports, and other logistical support. Disbursements under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB’s TA Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended).
